Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Dharmaraká¹£a of the Western Jin Dynasty
Hears this sort of: once the Buddha was traveling in RÄjagá¹›ha on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain, together with a great
assembly of 1,250 bhiká¹£us and innumerable mahÄsattvas.
At that time, in the city, the first wife of General Siá¹ƒha was pregnant with a virtuous son. A great voice was proclaimed from the empty sky, saying:
Child!

You should embrace the teachings of the Way and contemplate the scriptures. Be careful not to speak worldly words and phrases. Understand the expedient means of the Dharma that transcends the world. Speak little and use few words. Abandon worldly affairs. Return to the true meaning and do not take up beautifully worded and ornate teachings.

The child heard this voice from afar, never cried, and did not make a sound. He never showed the appearance of an infant. For seven days, his countenance was joyful and free from weariness. The people who came to see him never tired of it.
Some people said:
This child has no voice, so why raise him?
The parents replied:
This is not a matter of fate. We will raise him.
Why is that?
Now, observing this child, his majestic appearance is upright and wondrous, lofty and immeasurable, not something ordinary people can attain. It is truly not false.
At that time, the parents, relatives, and acquaintances saw that the child had no voice, so they named him No Words.
Then, the child No Words gradually grew up to the age of eight. The people from all directions who came to observe him never tired of it.

In whatever direction there was a Dharma assembly where the meaning was being distinguished, he would go there to consult and receive the Dharma words, silently contemplating in stillness, also not saying anything.

On another day, the young boy, together with his parents, five kinds of relatives, friends, and acquaintances, went to Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain and approached the Buddha. He bowed at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, stood in front of the World-Honored One with palms joined, and saw the assemblies of bodhisattvas from countless worlds in the ten directions, each sitting on a majestic and pure seat. He was greatly delighted and gave rise to wholesome thoughts.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra came forward and said to the Buddha:
Only the Heavenly Honored One!

This son of the general Siá¹ƒha, the speechless one, is upright and handsome with immeasurable majestic radiance, so lofty like this. He is free from speech and does not say anything. What remaining misfortune did he have in his past life, being born without a voice and unable to speak?
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
Stop, stop!
Do not rashly look down on the speechless youth.
Why is it so?

This person is then a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who has planted various roots of virtue with past buddhas, made offerings to innumerable buddhas and realized ones, bowed at their feet and attained irreversibility, and will surely accomplish the unsurpassed true path.
When he was first born, the heavens proclaimed in the sky:
'Child, you should embrace the intention of the Way, contemplate the scriptures and have no worldly talk.

' For this reason, this bodhisattva is now silent and does not speak. He has accepted gentle guidance for eight years, single-mindedly clenching his tongue and saying nothing, respectfully practicing the four dhyÄnas in this tranquil state.
The World-Honored One further said to ÅšÄriputra:

If there are sentient beings who can see Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Speech and completely follow the teachings of the Way because of his silence, for this reason there is now a great assembly, where he will expound the Dharma and transform and benefit innumerable and incalculable multitudes of people.

Then the Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Intent immediately entered the samÄdhi as it is, manifesting auspicious signs, causing the Å›rÄvakas, bodhisattvas, devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs in the assembly to each give rise to lotus flowers in their right palms, as large as chariot wheels, with various colors, subtle and beautiful, their fragrance immeasurable, delightful to behold.
Above those lotus flowers were naturally manifested bodhisattvas, sitting cross-legged with their bodies adorned by the thirty-two marks.

The Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Intent, seeing these great spiritual powers, bowed his head to the World-Honored One and took refuge in him. The bodhisattvas sitting above the lotus flowers, with palms joined and bodies bowed, also took refuge in him three times.

As soon as Bodhisattva Inexpressible spoke these words of homage and surrender, the worlds of the Buddhas, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, shook six times, and a great sound was heard everywhere. The heavens in the sky exclaimed like thunder and rained down various flowers, and the musical instruments such as lutes and pipes sounded by themselves without being played.

Bodhisattva Inexpressible, by the Buddha's majestic spiritual power and his own great vows, rose up into the sky to a height of forty-nine feet, and the great assembly of Bodhisattvas also did the same.
Bodhisattva Inexpressible, together with the Bodhisattvas, spoke in unison with these verses in praise of the Buddha:ğŸ”½Without form, yet manifesting form,
Not dwelling in form,ğŸ”½Desiring to enlighten the multitudes,
Manifesting a body with teachings.ğŸ”½The Buddha is the assembly without form,
Not attached to conditioned existence,ğŸ”½Delivering all beings,
The guide thus manifests a body.ğŸ”½Manifesting the thirty-two marks,
And the eighty minor marks,
Adorn their physical bodies, and expound the Dharma for the assembly.
The Dharma is without characteristics, and also without sound or echo,
Without sound, it cannot be obtained, without thought, it is tranquil and subtle.
The Buddha's Dharma is the enlightened Dharma, dwelling under the Bodhi tree,
That path is without verbal teachings, words have nothing to say.
The Dharma is a formless Dharma, seeking characteristics cannot be obtained,
Using a Dharma without characteristics, how can it have anything to say?
Having compassion for the multitude of beings, this is the Buddha's great kindness,
Discerning without gain, what is said is not lost in time.
Understanding without attainment, realizing emptiness without gain,
Those who can nurture in this way, the Buddha's meaning has no names or words.
The teachings of conditioned arising, all Buddhas speak of them due to causes,
Those numbers have no existence, the unconditioned has no naturalness.
Just as the formless form of impermanence, the guide sees the elephant,
This Dharma is non-existent, for the sake of the assembly, he expounds this sÅ«tra.
Moreover, from birth to eight years old, the mouth has never spoken,
When I was first born, the devas sang in great voices.
Entering the sÅ«tras, the ears do not hear sounds,
Thus bearing the Way's work, the mouth also has nothing to say.
Without words, there is a provisional teaching, with speech, there is nothing to express,
Using words, it is said to have a teaching, pure and wondrously radiant.
Thinking of the vow of the Buddha's Way, the aspiration is in the Great Vehicle,
One should proclaim the honored teaching, and attain Buddhahood as the supreme among humans.
The mind of the Way cannot be obtained, without words, without the thought of characteristics,
Therefore it is said the Way is empty, understanding and forming illuminates.
Then the youth said to the assembly:
The Way is the same as the teachings, it cannot be seen,
it cannot be held,

what can be spoken of cannot be perceived. Speaking with the mouth about the Way, people reckon the Way and seek for it, but where it is wished for, there is nothing, where it cannot be obtained, there is no dwelling. Dwelling like this is where the Way is established!
The perfections are also like this.
And the countless other roots of virtue, speaking of the teachings is also nothing to speak of, it is just sound without words.

Moreover, speaking of giving, giving should be given, giving with something to face, the Way abides in all equalities, speaking with the mouth about compassionate giving, the Way teaches also practicing kindness, the Way is naturally equal, like empty space, what is understood and spoken of in the mind, reckoning all of it is pure, the Way is universally empty like this.
Bodhisattvas' physical actions, speech, and thoughts are all dedicated to the elimination of afflictions, which is called the perfection of giving.
Encouraging and assisting others should also be like this.
Giving is not the grace of the Way. Those who consider the Way do not rely on giving. These two things are merely sounds.
They are ultimately without attachment and without form.
If one accepts the teachings of the Way in this way, it is the practice of a bodhisattva. That is called the perfection of giving.
For the giver, it is pure, because there is no expectation of reward.
Hearing the precepts with the ears, not dwelling on form, is neither born nor extinguished. This is also like the precepts.

If the body, speech, and mind do not create anything, they are all nonexistent, yet they are distinguished and explained as being formed from causes and conditions.ğŸ”½What is said by the mouth is called the precepts.
The precepts are also like this, as spoken by the mouth.
These two things are both formless, and all precepts and actions are merely verbal expressions without any written words. Those who reckon the Way have nothing to say.

What is spoken by the mouth and what is thought by the mind, using actions to encourage and assist the Way, saying that precepts are the Way, wanting to illuminate the precepts, all are formless like empty space. Being able to understand this is called the retribution of precepts that are practiced alone.
The mind that can be wandered in transcends and is unsurpassed, entering the profound and subtle Way that is difficult to attain in the equal enlightenment.
Then, he praised in verse:
As it is said, the Way is also thus, not grasped and invisible,
What is spoken is not seen, I proclaim the Buddha's Way.
Vowing to seek the Way, the vow abides nowhere,
Abiding nowhere, with no location, the Way that is established is also thus.
The perfections are also thus, and the various virtues that are created,
Words rely on sound, but what is spoken is ineffable.
What is called giving, what is given, and what is to be given,
What is to be practiced, all abide in the path of equality.
What is spoken of giving, and what is expounded about the way,
That way is also natural, equal, and like empty space.
If one can understand the mind, and what is spoken of by the mouth,
Then all of that is pure, and hearing the purity, one attains the way.
Body, speech, and mental thoughts, abandoning all afflictions,
What is encouraged is also like this, this is the perfection of giving.
Giving does not return to the way, the way does not rely on giving,
These two are provisional names, without attachment and without characteristics.
If there is no reliance, then receiving the way is like this,
If one does not expect reward, this is called giving.
Yet, hearing about the precepts, one does not dwell in form and appearance,
Not arising, not extinguishing, this is the characteristic of the precepts.
Not practicing the precepts is also like this, body, speech, and mind are no different,
No action, no existence, only provisional verbal expression!
The combination of causes and conditions has words, which are called the precepts!
As my precepts are equal, these two things are without outflows.
All matters of the precepts are provisional in words,
What is obtained through the meaning of the Way has no words and no action.
What is spoken by the mouth and done by the mind, the precepts assist the Way,
Counting the precepts and the teachings of the Way, all are like empty space.
If one understands this, one can walk alone and enter the precepts,
Then one can dwell in the Way, in the profound and wonderful difficult to understand words.
The youth also said to those who had come to the assembly:
What is called the teaching of patience is also words. Understanding the meaning of emptiness is called patience.
Patience is equal to the three realms, which are also equal. It is said that patience has no form or appearance, and equality of mind towards this is called patience.

If one can be patient and tranquil, the faculties of patience, sounds, smells, and tastes are formed from causes and conditions, but they do not exist, they are just words. Therefore, it is proclaimed as patience.
The TathÄgata's right enlightenment speaks of three kinds of patience: physical, verbal, and mental.
If one can understand this patience, it is called patience.
Understanding the cutting off of the body, with each part separated, the mind is without anger. Kindness, love, and the body are like walls. Observing the body in this way is patience.
Far hearing of the evil spoken, if one can endure it, not relishing the words spoken, that is patience.

If one's mind is tranquil and free from worries and knots, and the mind is able to discern all written words, then the mind enters into patience. Calculating like the path of patience is also like this, and body, speech, and mind are all the same, and this is called the path.

As for those who proclaim and transmit the teachings of the sages and encourage many, all the supreme, subtle, and intermediate forms of vigor accumulated over billions of eons cannot be attained, let alone accomplished.
If vigor cannot be attained, and calculating the path of morality also results in nothing gained, and the various dharmas are not attained, this is called vigor.

If the vigor cultivated is like this, without harboring cowardice or fear, this is called the supreme, vast, vigorous, and courageous great vigor of the bodhisattva who is fully endowed with benevolence and righteousness.
Then the youth spoke a verse, saying:
It is called patience, what is proclaimed by the mouth,
The meaning of emptiness and emptiness is forbearance, like forbearance and the three times.
It is said that the appearance of forbearance cannot be seen by the eyes,
If the mind is like this, it is called forbearance.
The type of forbearance is empty and still, conditioned by sound, smell, and taste,
It has no written language, this is called forbearance.
Expounding these three forbearances, of body, speech, and mind,
If a person understands this, it is called forbearance.
Cutting off one's body limb by limb, the mind does not harbor anger,
The body experiences like a wall, this is physical forbearance.
Hearing far away there are evil words, not repaying abusive speech,
Entering this sound is forbearance, all able to abide in what is said.
If towards all faults, the mind does not harbor love and attachment,
If able to understand the emptiness of written language, this is the mind entering forbearance.
Just as with the path of patience, so it is with body, speech, and mind.ğŸ”½This is called the path,
And is called the encouragement of what is to be done.ğŸ”½If one exerts effort in all things,
Whether supreme, middling, or lesser,ğŸ”½Accumulating for billions of eons,
One will not attain accomplishment.ğŸ”½Effort cannot be attained,
And the path also has nothing to be gained.ğŸ”½Not reaching any dharma,
This is called effort.ğŸ”½If one practices with diligent strength,
Without fear or difficulty,ğŸ”½That is great effort,
For the courageous bodhisattva.
The youth further said to those who had come to the assembly:
So-called meditation also does not have thoughts. Considering meditation, it also has nowhere to abide. Abandoning all thoughts, this is called the perfection of tranquil liberation.
Then one can be tranquil, serene, without words, without negligence, free from all defilements, and burn and extinguish all dust. This is called the perfection of tranquil liberation.
The mind does not send thoughts back and forth to phenomena, and the mind is apart from the mind - this is called the perfection of tranquility.

The mind and meditation always reach the intention of the Way, and always observe these matters with equality. If one can be equal, then there is neither right nor wrong in all that is observed. This is called the Buddha Way, which is not difficult to attain;
There are no written words and nothing to say, it cannot be ultimately reached and does not exist, there is no negligence and one does not indulge oneself - this is called the perfection of wisdom.

There is no this shore and no crossing to the other shore, and one does not dwell in this or that. Establishing the Dharma realm without dwelling, without attachment, without written words, without proclamation, without written words -
No longer raising false thoughts. If one can receive and accept this Dharma, then it is called the perfection of wisdom.

The six pÄramitÄs are also like this. If someone can equally contemplate this meaning, then they will be able to harmonize all dharmas and also be equal to all sentient beings. If they can be the same as all dharmas, then they will be able to harmonize all sentient beings. If they can harmonize all sentient beings, then they will be able to be equal to all Buddhas.
Having been equal to the Buddhas, then they will be able to respectfully cultivate the omniscience. Therefore, the bodhisattva is courageous and fearless, and this is called the pÄramitÄ of wisdom.
If one can follow this teaching, then one will follow the inconceivable Dharma eye.
Then the youth spoke a verse, saying:
The practice of meditation is without thought, the focused mind is without abiding,
Cutting off all thoughts, it is called the pÄramitÄ of tranquility.
Tranquil and serene, without indulgence and without defilements,
Abandoning all afflictions, this is the pÄramitÄ of tranquility.
The mind of all dharmas has never gone or returned,
Without mind, liberated from mind, peacefully crossing to the other shore.
Calculating the mind and the Way, observing them all to be equal,
If one can discern equality, the Buddha Way is not difficult to attain.
Abandoning written words and speech, without basis and nothing existent,
Not enjoying and not indulging oneself, this is called wisdom.
Without this, not crossing the shore, not dwelling in the middle,
Correctly standing in the Dharma realm, not dwelling, not attached.
Written words are not proclaimed, not associated with any thoughts,
By this, accepting all dharmas, this is called wisdom.
The perfections are thus, what is seen is of the same kind,ğŸ”½Then one can be equal to all dharmas, and impartial towards sentient beings.
By being able to be equal to all dharmas, one can be equal to sentient beings,
They are also equal to all dharmas, and thus equal to all wisdom.
Therefore, the great wisdom of the bodhisattvas is courageous and resolute,
Able to follow this teaching, the Dharma eye is inconceivable.

Those upright ones, speaking these verses and discerning their destination, with twelve hundred people all giving rise to the intention for unsurpassed, true enlightenment, and sixty thousand bodhisattvas attaining acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

At that time, the bodhisattvas seated on the lotuses immediately descended, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and again paid homage to the bodhisattva Inexhaustible, together requesting the bodhisattva Inexhaustible, saying:
We repay the kindness of the holy teacher, respectfully enjoy the true Dharma, serve the scriptures, and practice filial obedience with gratitude.
The worthy Shariputra then addressed the Buddha, saying:
Yes, World-Honored One!
Why do these bodhisattvas proclaim the Tathagata's words with their mouths, saying:
'We are filial and grateful'?
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:

All these bodhisattvas were inspired by the great being Bodhisattva Inexhaustible, causing them to proclaim the teachings of the Way, to expound on kindness, benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and the unsurpassed true great vehicle teachings, to enlighten those who have not yet heard and cause them to give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment. This is being filial and obedient, and having gratitude and repayment.

Repaying the kindness of the teacher, they have now come to make offerings and cultivate virtue, and also wish to witness this great assembly, to venerate the Buddha, and to listen to and accept the sutras they hear.
Then Bodhisattva Inexhaustible addressed the World-Honored One, saying:
I wish to ask the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One about the doubts in my mind. If I am permitted, I will dare to speak.
The World-Honored One then told Bodhisattva Inexhaustible:
Ask freely about what you do not understand. The TathÄgata will explain each and every one for you, satisfying your mind and leaving no doubts.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra said to the Bodhisattva of No Words:
You, son of a good family, are unable to speak. How can you wish to ask the TathÄgata about the meaning?
No Words replied:
All dharmas of speech are devoid of written characters and also devoid of words.
Why is it so?
All sentient beings are naturally devoid of teachings and various thoughts.
Only ÅšÄriputra!
Because of thoughts in the mind, one speaks with the mouth. If there is nothing to think, then there is nothing to say.
What the mind thinks is all empty and unreal. Words cannot be spoken, cannot be shown to others, and also cannot be consulted or inquired about.
Those who are attached to thoughts have nothing, and there are no written characters.
That which is empty and nonexistent also has no thoughts, and does not proclaim the teachings of written characters.
Those who practice and think do not think to themselves:
'I will proclaim the teachings of written characters.'
The written words do not think, but the thought of practice flows through the written words and is expressed.
Only ÅšÄriputra!
The twelve links of dependent origination are profound and difficult to attain, lofty like this, born from causes and conditions, they are then natural, with nothing existing;
If it is natural and nothing exists, then there is no one who attains the Way.
Only ÅšÄriputra!

All dharmas have no accomplishment, the matter of causes and conditions relies on nothing to abide, and something is created, because of the combination of conditions, therefore causes and conditions have nothing to establish.
Only ÅšÄriputra!

All dharmas have no master, and the ruler also has no permanent master, there is no intention, because of one's own thoughts one runs in many places, from the presence of thoughts one dwells in various thoughts, the party of inverted views arises from it.
If they have questions or see difficult questions, all these dharmas, with or without thought, are all of one characteristic, namely, without thought.
The reason for their questions is that the bodhisattvas practice great compassion.
Only ÅšÄriputra!

For this reason, I give rise to great compassion and ask the TathÄgata, not asking about matters of speech and sound, relying on oral teachings, but abiding in great compassion, the bodhisattvas' questions.
ÅšÄriputra asked:
If, son of a good family, there are no sentient beings and no people, for what reason does the bodhisattva give rise to great compassion for sentient beings?
Wumen replied:
Only ÅšÄriputra!
If sentient beings do not seek to accomplish reaching the Way, then the bodhisattva would not give rise to great compassion for sentient beings;
However, sentient beings have no sentient beings, giving rise to the thought of sentient beings, therefore the bodhisattva abides in sentient beings and gives rise to great compassion.
If it is said that there are people, then it is rebellious. All five destinies are like illusions and transformations.
Alas, how painful!
All people are upside down, without the notion of sentient beings. Therefore, for their sake, I expound the scriptures and principles, so that the beginning and end of no-self are all empty.

For this reason, the bodhisattva arouses great compassion for all sentient beings, without destroying anything or damaging what exists. He does not destroy the self, the person, or life. Therefore, it is said that the bodhisattva enters great compassion and guides and benefits sentient beings.

Seeing through and discerning the empty events, being tainted by the guests and dust, being able to enter and equalize all forms, and seeing that they are originally all pure, for this reason the bodhisattva arouses great compassion for sentient beings.
At that time, Shariputra praised Inexpressible Bodhisattva, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
It is truly as you have said, without any difference.
Moreover, I wish to ask about the eloquence that the benevolent and wise one has been expounding to the listeners. I wish to inquire about this inconceivable [teaching] from the noble one.

The Dharma that has been proclaimed, if asked about, should enable the evil Mara to find no opportunity, cause the Tathagata's Dharma to endure for a long time, and cause this assembly of devas, nagas, yakshas, gandharvas, asuras, garudas, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans to attain the light of the Dharma of immeasurable paths.
Then the Bodhisattva Inexpressible addressed the Buddha, saying:
The World-Honored One has always said that those who cultivate right view have two causes and conditions:
Listening to the teachings of others and contemplating their practice.
Excellent!
Great Sage!
I only wish that the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, would explain and proclaim this.
What is meant by bodhisattvas relying on the teachings of others?
What is meant by contemplation?
What is the right view of the sages?
The Buddha told the Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Mind:
Son of a good family!
Listen carefully and ponder it well, and I will now explain it for you.
It is just like a bodhisattva who receives the sounds of others, and then contemplates, and respectfully follows the correct view of the sages.
Excellent!
World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear it.
The Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Mind, together with the great assembly, accepted the teaching and listened.
The Buddha said:
Son of a good family!
If there are bodhisattvas who encourage sentient beings to enter the Buddha's path, this is the bodhisattvas receiving the sounds of others;
If the mind does not harbor confusion, this is contemplation;
If one equally observes the intention of the path, this is the correct view of the sages.
Moreover, if one listens to and reflects on the flexible and compliant Dharma, this is receiving the sounds of others;
If one is able to uphold the meaning of the Buddha's path, this is contemplation;
If one is able to uphold the bodhisattva path and attain the acceptance of the Dharma, this is the correct view of the sages.
Furthermore, Aniruddha!

If one is able to proclaim the subtle wisdom that is heard, the unsurpassed true reality, and by relying on these words of others, if one is able to penetrate and not conceive of a self, this is contemplation;
if one's nature is pure and without flattery, and one initiates vast activities, this is the correct view of the sages.
Listening to the meaning that accords with the Dharma without contradicting the teachings is relying on the words of others;
cultivating various roots of virtue is contemplation;
if one's practice is subtle and one encourages the path, this is the correct view of the sages.
Single-mindedly listening and receiving is relying on the words of others;
seeking the extraordinary meaning is contemplation;
encouraging the intention of the path and never forgetting or abandoning it is the correct view of the sages.

In accordance with recollection, one should assist the path with the mind, not neglecting the equal observation of the sages from the beginning, and letting go of all that can be heard and remembered, this is listening to others;
All that can be respected, one is able to give without stinginess, this is reflection;
Not expecting its reward, not greedily attached to the path, reaching the Great Vehicle, this is the correct view of the sages.
Listening to the teachings of the precepts that are vast and magnanimous, this is listening to others;
The mind that grasps the precepts has nothing to practice or abandon, this is reflection;
The precepts have nothing to practice, firmly believing in the truth and assisting the path, this is the correct view of the sages.
Listening to the forbearance, benevolence, righteousness, and great compassion, this is listening to others;
While harboring pity, having no harmful thoughts, this is reflection;
Ultimately tranquil, believing in the exhaustion of all dharmas and assisting the Buddha's path, this is the correct view of the sages.
Listening and contemplating with diligence, and following it, is receiving the teachings of others;
Not dwelling in the mind of laziness and defilement is contemplation;
Without aggregation or dispersion, without error, diligently and vigorously encouraging the path is the noble right view.
Hearing about the three liberations and the three concentrations of meditation is receiving the teachings of others;
The mind's activities cannot be attained, observing the mind's origin is contemplation;
The cultivation of meditation does not fall into error and encourages the Buddha's path, which is the noble right view.
Listening to the wisdom, body, faculties, flowers, and fruits is receiving the teachings of others;
The observed phenomena are investigated from beginning to end, which is contemplation;
Abandoning the various streams and cliffs, opening up and transforming the mind's intentions is the noble right view.
Demonstrating the four kinds of kindness, listening and embracing what is heard without attachment is receiving the teachings of others;
Never abandoning the teachings of the four kinds of kindness, this is reflection;

Being able to rescue and benefit sentient beings with kindness and compassion, this is the principle of equality, and to liberate and establish them in omniscience, this is the correct view of the sages.
Cultivating the four kinds of brahma conduct of kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, this is listening to others;
But not destroying or harming sentient beings with pity and love, and not destroying anything, and what is to be practiced is not seeking fame, this is reflection;

Following the joy of emptiness, for the sake of sentient beings cultivating compassion, for the sake of the Dharma practicing joy, and for the two kinds of rewards encouraging and assisting the Way, this is the correct view of the sages.
If one listens to and contemplates the four kinds of analytical eloquence, this is listening to others;
Observing all dharmas and deportment, this is reflection;
From the Dharma and meaning being equal, the practice being complete encourages the intention of the Way, this is the correct view of the sages.
If one hears what should be upheld and practices the subtle and beneficial matters, this is called hearing from others;
To contemplate and follow without being apart from them is called contemplation;
The path of the chapters and sentences, from which the Buddha's path is expounded, is called the correct view of the sages.
If one can cause others to hear the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and the true Dharma, this is called hearing from others;

Cultivating the mindfulnesses without confusion, practicing the abandonment of thoughts, never following a mind of non-virtue, always conforming to virtuous intentions, the spiritual powers being diligent and concentrated without cowardice, having such firm faith, clearly understanding the chapters and sentences without retreating, wisdom being able to seek out and observe each and every thing, the mind being powerful and not engaging in afflictions, entering the factors of enlightenment and being equal-minded towards the path, this is called contemplation;

If one has no mind and no thoughts, in the four bases of mindfulness one neither arises nor ceases, in the four right efforts one harmonizes body and mind, in the four bases of supernatural power one discerns as true, understanding in this way, one's destination is like this, wielding the sword of wisdom to cut off various defilements, emotional desires are not scattered, one enters the true Dharma, and in the enlightenment factors one enters equality without two things, one's return is the path, and one encourages the mind of the Way. This is the correct view of the sages.
If one listens to the four noble truths, this is following the sounds of others;
the suffering of the five aggregates, the difficulties of affection and love, the extinction of the causes and conditions of practice, and entering the path, this is contemplation;

although dwelling in various sufferings, wisdom does not arise, in various practices wisdom does not practice, in various exhaustions wisdom ultimately exhausts, in the path wisdom is unattached, and one encourages the great Way. This is the correct view of the sages.
If one listens and receives the three gates of liberation, this is hearing the Dharma from others;
Deeply believing in emptiness, not fearing the signless, and not aspiring for anything in the wishless, this is contemplation;
Not giving rise to empty practices, but transforming all views, giving rise to the signless to guide all, and giving rise to the wishless in all activities, this is the noble right view.
Causing those who have first given rise to the mind to follow the great practices, this is hearing the Dharma from others;
Cultivating bodhisattva practices without abandoning anything, this is contemplation;
The stage of nonretrogression, where one will attain perfect enlightenment, this is the noble right view.
Obtaining good spiritual friends and following their teachings, this is hearing the Dharma from others;
Seeing the World-Honored One with one's own eyes and consulting the noble path, this is contemplation;
As one speaks, one does not contradict one's words, and body and speech correspond, this is the noble right view.
Listening to the Dharma that is expounded, which is equal to confusion, this is hearing the Dharma from others;
Contemplating the ultimate meaning of all dharmas is reflection;
Upholding the meaning of the Dharma without losing the teachings of the Way is the correct view of the sages.
Approaching the TathÄgata and receiving what he proclaims is listening to others;
Discerning the Way with the mind and not abandoning the great principles is reflection;
Receiving and upholding the teachings and being able to transform and accomplish them is the correct view of the sages.
If one is able to listen to and receive the eighty-four thousand dharmas of the path, this is listening to others;
Clearly discerning the eighty-four thousand practices of the buddhas is reflection;
Teaching the Dharma according to the different capacities of the eighty-four thousand kinds of sentient beings is the correct view of the sages.
Wherever one is, having no attachment and giving rise to a virtuous mind is listening to others;
If one's mind does not abandon virtue, this is reflection;
With this virtue, the mind is focused and dedicated to all-wisdom. This is the correct view of the sages.
If this son of a great clan follows and contemplates, he will have a long life span, immeasurable and beginningless, and the correct view of the sages.
Why is it so?
The five destinies revolve like an illusion, a transformation, a dream, a shadow, an echo, a mirage, the moon in the water, or a plantain. Understanding this is following the teachings of others;
all dharmas are equal and without partiality or perversity. This is contemplation;
if one attains equality, it is the correct view of the sages.

It is called contemplation, neither exalted nor low. In all dharmas, there is no correspondence or non-correspondence, no progress or non-progress, no place or non-place, no practice or non-practice, no recollection or non-recollection, no thought or non-thought, no intention or non-intention, no consideration or non-consideration, no mind or mental activity. This is called the non-dual entry into the Dharma gate.
Understanding a single item, there is no combination, no dispersion, no opposition, no conformity.

Understanding the profound, contemplating the originally pure nature, extremely radiant, one should expound without darkness, without light, without turbidity, without clarity, without sequence, it is the Dharma realm, without destruction, and at the fundamental point, without movement or agitation.

Entering the rootless, abiding in the three times without abiding, without self, without person, without life, without destiny, without sound, without voice, equal to all written words, the meaning is unattainable, without wealth and occupation, without completion, attaining all that is exhausted, all practices without various thoughts.
Free from all thoughts, completely severing careless acts, eliminating all contemplated practices, without attachment, abandoning all attachments, lofty, up to the praise of the TathÄgata!
The unconditioned matter is to cut off all thoughts, which is called equality. It has no form and appearance, and should be contemplated accordingly.

If the practitioner arises from samÄdhi, he should use this Dharma to explain it to sentient beings and others. He should then seek the basis of this [Dharma] and treat it by contemplating it as appropriate, without any movement. This is called establishing great compassion and the correct view of the sages.
When the Buddha spoke of the correct view of the sages, ten thousand bodhisattvas immediately attained the correct view of the sages.
Then ÅšÄriputra said to the bodhisattva Inexhaustible:
Virtuous son of noble family!
From whom did you hear the Dharma that you were able to give rise to this correct view of the sages?
Inexhaustible replied:
Only ÅšÄriputra!
The Dharma that I have heard is unconditioned. It is not attained through the mind of the past, nor is it attained through the future or the present.
The equality of the three times is equal to all dharmas, those who exist and those who do not return, there are no dharmas, and there is nothing to be equal to;
I listen to the Dharma from them.

Not existent, not non-existent, no consciousness, no dwelling, no mind, no thought, no consciousness, do not revere any dharmas, restrain the minds of all beings, delight all people, gain nothing in meaning, and do not waver, in powerless poison, without attachment;
I correctly listen to the Dharma from them.
Seeing those born in the world are unborn and unarisen, all dharmas if not arisen, distinguish the rootless and have nothing to say;
I correctly listen to the Dharma from them.

Those who abide in the dharma realm equally govern the realm of people, the dharma realm, the realm of people, and the realm of space are not differentiated, the various realms are equal and unborn, not creating various;
I correctly listen to the Dharma from them.

He did not dwell in the place of enlightenment, did not sit under the tree, did not walk back and forth, did not attain Buddhahood, did not rely on the Way, did not abandon the world, and did not cause the people who were attached to these thoughts to think like this.

The TathÄgata's attainment of the Way is also not the attainment of the Way. The attainment of the major and minor marks, whether or not the attainment of the marks, the realization or non-realization, all arise from the originally pure natural nature.

Since there is no birth, there is no arising. Since there is no arising, there is no end. Since there is no end, there is no attachment. Since there is no attachment, there is no shaking. Having already roamed in the swift waters, there is nothing to be attained. Having already attained nothing, the body crosses to the other shore. Having already crossed to the other shore,

The other shore has no lower part. Without a lower part, there is no vessel. Having no vessel, there is nothing to correspond to. Having nothing to correspond to, one leaves off desire. Having left off desire, there are no thoughts. Having no thoughts, one cuts off all disturbances. Having cut off all disturbances, the fundamental nature is pure, and one reaches purity.

The other shore has no lower part. Without a lower part, there is no vessel. Having no vessel, there is nothing to correspond to. Having nothing to correspond to, one departs from desire. Having departed from desire, there are no thoughts. Having no thoughts, one cuts off various disturbances. Having cut off various disturbances, the fundamental nature is pure. Having attained purity, there is no defilement. Having no defilement, there is no afflictive dust. Having no afflictive dust, there is no likeness. Having no likeness, one abides in equality. Abiding in fundamental equality, one establishes

unmovability. Establishing unmovability, there is nothing to seek. Having nothing to seek, it is like true reality. Having conformed to true reality, it is like thorough truth. one crosses over the realm. Having crossed over the various realms, what arises is non-arising, and thus there is nothing to lift up. Having nothing to lift up,
What is raised is without what is lowered, and because there is nothing lowered, there is no gate. Because there is no gate,
one departs from verbal teachings. Because one departs from verbal teachings, one crosses over the phrases of consciousness. Because one crosses over the phrases of consciousness, one
no longer returns. Because one no longer returns, there is no place. Because there is no place, there is no non-place.

The correct view is to regard oneself as equal to others. By regarding oneself as equal to others, one is free from union and separation. By being free from union and separation, one does not see equality in all things that are equal, and one sees all that is seen as if it were no thought.
This is what Shariputra proclaims as the wise and holy correct view of the Dharma and Vinaya.
The Bodhisattva Inexhaustible said to Shariputra:

If one regards ignorance, love, and attachment as equal, and also regards wisdom, clarity, and liberation as equal, and regards nirvana as neither existent nor nonexistent, this is called attaining the wise and holy correct view;
If one sees something but does not grasp it as a different view, this is the wise and holy correct view.
Furthermore, think about it.
Shariputra!

If one can regard lust, anger, and delusion as equal, and also regard emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness as equal, then the characteristics of liberation are one characteristic, namely, returning to signlessness.
If one is able to return to this equal matter, this is the wise and holy correct view.

Furthermore, those who abide in right view do not create two things in all equalities, and having no two things, they do not abide in association. Having no association, they do not abide in anything and attain the equality of all dharmas without distinction. This is the right view of the sages.
Furthermore, equality without duality is the equality of sentient beings, the equality of all buddhas, and the equality of all dharmas.

Having equaled all dharmas, one then equals the lands. Having equaled the lands, one equals space. If one does not turn away from this equality, and is able to abide in this equality, cultivating without abiding anywhere, this is the right view of the sages.
Therefore, ÅšÄriputra!
Like the Dharma, the listener is also thus. Right view is like this.

Has the elder arisen in right view?

If there are those who do not wish for the TathÄgata's supreme virtue, then what they aspire to will be unequal, and there will be no partiality or perversity in desire or non-desire. Those who have something they aspire to will fall into lack.
ÅšÄriputra asked:
Only, son of a great clan!
What is meant by not lacking in the Dharma?
Wu-yan replied:

There is no great, no five aggregates, no six sense bases, no acceptance, no attraction, no activity, no words, no teaching or non-teaching, and in the Dharma of the Way, causing the mind and consciousness to arise nowhere. This Dharma is without lack;
If there is the arising of the mind and consciousness, then one falls into lack.
If in the various Dharmas there is creation or non-creation, then one falls into lack;
If in the various Dharmas there is neither creation nor non-creation, then there is no lack.
Furthermore, if in the various Dharmas there is discrimination, there is elimination, there is practice, and there is realization, then one falls into lack;
If there is no understanding, no removal of what is to be eliminated, no practice, and no realization, then there is no lack.
If there is something seen, something heard, something taught, and something reached through cognition, then one falls into lack;
if there is no practice in any realm, then there is no lack.
If there is seeing of merit and faults, then one falls into lack;
if there is practice without faults, without praise of merit and without seeing, then there is no lack.
At that time, the Buddha praised the Bodhisattva of No Words:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
If you wish to expound the Dharma, you should speak like this.
At that time, twelve thousand bodhisattvas attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The Bodhisattva of No Words further said to the Buddha:
I know that the TathÄgata expounds the four powers for bodhisattvas: first, the power of faith; second, the power of diligence; third, the power of intention; and fourth, the power of wisdom.
Only the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One, extensively distinguishes and explains these four kinds of powers.
What are the powers of faith, diligence, intention, and wisdom for bodhisattvas?
The Buddha told the bodhisattva Inexhaustible:
Listen carefully and keep it in mind!
Excellent!
World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear it.
The bodhisattva Inexhaustible accepted the teaching and listened.
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
If a bodhisattva has faith in the Buddha's teachings, loves and follows them without doubt or hesitation, this is the power of faith;
When the buddhas were originally seeking the Way, they aspired to this canon without laziness, without cowardice, and without turning back, this is the power of diligence;

If one gathers the mind and collects the roots of virtue without forgetting, the mind is not confused and does not abandon the aspiration for enlightenment, and one encourages the path with a true mind regarding what should be undertaken or abandoned, this is the power of intention;
The wisdom cultivated illuminates all dharmas, one does not need the wisdom of others and attains mastery, and wisdom is unobstructed, this is the power of wisdom.
The Buddha further said to Inexhaustible Mind Bodhisattva:
Faith in the sages, walking alone in the three realms without any doubts or difficulties, this is the power of faith;
The diligence and respectfulness one practices, this is the power of diligence;
Constantly thinking of what the sages proclaim in one's thoughts, never forgetting or abandoning it, this is the power of intention;
If one can practice what one hears of the wisdom and scriptures from the sages, this is the power of wisdom.
Furthermore, if one firmly believes in the retribution of sins and merits without doubt or confusion, this is the power of faith;
If one can diligently practice and not do what should not be done, this is the power of diligence;
If one can remember the deeds one has done and never let them go to waste, this is the power of intention;
If one can understand that there is no retribution for good or bad deeds, and can discern all dharmas, this is the power of wisdom.
The Buddha further told the Bodhisattva Inexhaustible:
If one can keep one's mind pure and undefiled, and be able to focus one's thoughts in accordance with the teachings of the Way, this is the power of faith;
If one can receive and nurture what the mind initiates, this is the power of diligence;
If one can always make one's mind follow the will and be unified, this is the power of intention;
If one can contemplate all dharmas as being like illusions, this is the power of wisdom.
Furthermore, if one has faith that all dharmas are empty, this is the power of faith;
If one cultivates diligence and resolves the bonds of views, this is the power of diligence;
If one is not afraid of inner and outer emptiness, this is the power of intention;
Contemplating ultimate emptiness, from beginning to end all is empty, this is the power of wisdom.
Without characteristics, without wishes, in all dharmas there is no action to be done, this is the power of faith;
Using these Dharma methods to distinguish and explain them to others, this is the power of diligence;
If one thinks about the practices of all dharmas in this way, this is the power of intention;
What was previously expounded and what is about to be proclaimed cannot be found anywhere, this is the power of wisdom.
All that exists should be contemplated by the mind, and one should wish to let go and give in places of faith and giving, this is the power of faith;
Letting go without feeling weary or ever cowardly, never going against the great path, and giving away with the intention of giving, this is the power of intention;
Neither the giver nor the receiver can be found, and there is no thought of reward, this is the power of wisdom.
Upholding the precepts and accomplishing true faith and precept fruition is the power of faith;
Using one's diligence to eliminate the mind of precept-breaking is the power of diligence;
If one contemplates the precepts with the mind of the Way and does not forget them, and uses all the upheld precepts to encourage and assist in omniscience, this is the power of intention;
Observing the body as a shadow, speech as an echo, and the mind as an illusion, and examining the precepts without any action, this is the power of wisdom.
Accomplishing patience and believing in authority is the power of faith;

The practiced diligence does not listen to various thoughts, does not speak coarse words to others, does not follow wrong paths, and if one's body is dismembered or cut apart, one gathers the power of patience and never harbors anger, patiently enduring with a compassionate mind, this is the power of diligence;
The practiced patience then encourages and assists in omniscience, this is the power of intention;
Without the consciousness of body and mind, the body and mind are not obtained, this is the power of wisdom.
The path is diligence, not laziness. Believing in this, the mind is joyful and flourishing with sincere faith. This is the power of faith.

Always practicing diligence without abandoning it for a moment, and also being unattached, using it to transform sentient beings, protecting the true canon, planting the roots of various merits, serving the Buddha and making offerings in accordance with [his teachings], all for the sake of all sentient beings, cultivating the Buddha's land and adorning it with purity and fame - this is the power of diligence.
Eliminating all the anger and laziness of sentient beings, wearing the armor of virtue and cultivating diligence, then encouraging and assisting in omniscience. This is the power of intention.

If one is not diligent and has false thoughts about the path, not losing the correctness of dignified deportment and etiquette, selecting diligence, not attaining the location of all dharmas, this is the power of wisdom.
Joyfully dwelling in solitude and quietude, not longing for the assembly, giving rise to the power of delight, this is the power of faith;
The power of vigor is to cultivate meditation and concentration, and to give rise to the doors of liberation and meditative absorptions.
The power of mind is to be unmoved by the causes and conditions that lead to meditative absorption.

The power of skillful means is to contemplate impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self with a single mind, without disturbing meditation, without despising meditation, without regressing in meditation, and to skillfully understand and adapt to the situation, guiding and leading others to the power of wisdom.
The power of faith is to hear about all the perfections, the factors of the path, and the Dharma, and to be able to have faith in them.

The power of vigor is to remember and not forget everything one hears, to praise skillful means for others, to be able to follow or not follow those teachings, and to examine one's own past and future.
The power of mind is to be unmoved by sentient beings, to roam in desires like a lotus flower, and to teach and transform all.

Observing the emptiness of the three realms, like a mirage, a plantain, a wild horse, a shadow, an echo, an illusion, or a transformation, revealing what has not been heard before, this is the power of wisdom.
With a pure and clear mind, being kind towards sentient beings and benevolent without exception, this is the power of faith;
Faith in great compassion, the mind's activities not being lazy, this is the power of vigor;
The mind delighting in the true canon, not abandoning the joy of the Dharma and always upholding and practicing it, this is the power of intention;
The mind being unattached and not harboring harm, not creating duality, without progress or non-progress, attaining tranquil observation and practicing the true Dharma, this is the power of wisdom.

Contemplating the human body, with countless evil flaws and disturbances, not being able to last long, making offerings to this unruly and venomous snake, due to wrong conduct, understanding this, this is the power of faith;
If one quickly falls into the suffering of the masses, and various afflictions arrive together, this is the meaning of birth and death. Contemplating the Buddha's teachings is the power of diligence;

If the mind changes and is in non-goodness, one never listens to it, and the mind also does not follow the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas. Moreover, the mind does not follow dust, desires, greed, or jealousy. The mind also does not follow the destruction of precepts and evil wisdom. This is the power of intention;
If one enters the wisdom of the Dharma and the phrases of wisdom, enters the wisdom of proclamation and understanding, and the wisdom of the past, future, and present, this is the power of wisdom.

Joy is the characteristic of faith, the characteristic of diligence is non-retrogression, contemplation is the characteristic of intention, and understanding is the characteristic of wisdom. Practicing the power of faith, not abandoning the power of diligence, not losing the power of intention, and cultivating the power of wisdom.
Explaining the Dharma for people and giving medicine according to the illness, understanding obstructions is called firm faith;
Transcending all obstructions is called diligence;
Not attaching to anything again is called intention;
And if one thoroughly understands and eliminates obstacles, it becomes wisdom.
If one delights in the Buddha Dharma and gives rise to sincere faith, and if one gives rise to sincere faith and thus gives rise to the intention for enlightenment, this is the power of faith;
If one practices various practices and accumulates the dharmas of the path, this is the power of vigor;
If one is in accord with the forbearance of the Dharma, this is the power of intention;
If one attains the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, this is the power of wisdom.
The root of faith is forbearance, which is the power of intention;
If one attains the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, this is the power of wisdom.
The root of faith is the power of faith;
The root of vigor is the power of vigor;
The root of intention is the power of intention;
The root of the subjugation of meditation is the power of wisdom that reaches everywhere.
